results.abstract: British director David Sington tells story of space race to achieve first lunar landing in documentary In the Shadow of the Moon; Apollo crew members are interviewed in film; photos (M)

headline.main: Film Takes Us Back 38 Years, to That First Walk

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: IN THE SHADOW OF THE MOON (MOVIE)>

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: IN THE SHADOW OF THE MOON (MOVIE)

results.snippet: The new documentary “In the Shadow of the Moon” tells the story of the Apollo program and the race to reach the moon.
results.lead_paragraph: They are old men now. That much is obvious from the tight camera shots. Nonetheless, it is hard to fathom: has it been 38 years since the first of them set foot on lunar soil? ''In the Shadow of the Moon,'' a documentary that premieres this week in New York and Los Angeles, tells the story of the Apollo program and the race to reach the moon, as President John F. Kennedy declared in 1962, ''before this decade is out.'' And so, on July 20, 1969, we did.

results.abstract: Neil Genzlinger reviews premiere of live-action television series Out of Jimmy's Head starring Dominic Janes; photo (M)

headline.main: What's in a Seventh Grader's Head?

results.snippet: This is really just another show about a seventh grader trying to fit in. It’s also a show with a sly sense of humor when it’s not being self-consciously frenetic.
results.lead_paragraph: Perhaps it's unfair to expect the folks at the Cartoon Network to know this, but if you use human actors in your show, you really need to hire a hair wrangler. Dominic Janes, the young star of the network's first live-action series, which has its premiere tonight, has an early Kristy McNichol thing going up top, or maybe Mackenzie Phillips in ''One Day at a Time'': too much hair for his head size, too many waves for his age. And sloppy. Just because he's playing an awkward junior high school-age boy doesn't mean he has to look like one. Buy some scissors, for crying out loud.

results.abstract: Dave Kehr reviews new DVD versions of William Friedkin's 1980 film Cruising and boxed set of films starring Vincent Price; photos (M)
results.snippet: The enduring theme of William Friedkin’s 1980 film “Cruising” is the reality of evil and its uncomfortable proximity to sex.
results.lead_paragraph: CRUISING Controversial when it opened in 1980, William Friedkin's ''Cruising,'' a thriller about the search for a serial killer in that era's flourishing world of New York gay leather bars, generated only a murmur when it returned to theaters this month as a prelude to its DVD release today. The Village Voice, which led the protest against Mr. Friedkin's film even as it was being shot in the West Village, greeted the rerelease with condescension colored by a certain nostalgia:

results.abstract: Caryn James reviews Boomerang Theater Company production Stoppard Goes Electric, featuring Tom Stoppard plays Another Moon Called Earth, Teeth and A Separate Peace; photo of actors Kate Ross and Christopher Yeatts (M)

headline.main: Out of the Nest With Tom Stoppard, When He Was Learning to Soar

results.snippet: The three works grouped together as “Stoppard Goes Electric” may appeal to Tom Stoppard completists but probably no one else.
results.lead_paragraph: For some people -- and I'm certainly one -- even the least play by Tom Stoppard is more enticing than anything else onstage. The three works written for British television in the mid-1960s and grouped together as ''Stoppard Goes Electric'' may appeal to completists but probably no one else. They are uneven, given a shabby-chic production by the Boomerang Theater Company that could satisfy only a fledgling playwright. Mr. Stoppard was fledgling when he wrote them, of course. And although they are contemporary with his breakthrough ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,'' you can glimpse him finding his way.

results.abstract: Sputnik, tiny satellite that was launched by Russians on Oct 4, 1957, generated widespread concern that Russia had technical superiority over United States; achievement fueled perceived threat to security and is described as primary motivation for Apollo program and space race (M)

headline.main: With Fear and Wonder in Its Wake, Sputnik Lifted Us Into the Future

results.snippet: Sputnik changed everything - history, geopolitics, the scientific world. A reflection on the triumphs and disappointments of the space age.
results.lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, before most people living today were born, the beep-beep-beep of Sputnik was heard round the world. It was the sound of wonder and foreboding. Nothing would ever be quite the same again -- in geopolitics, in science and technology, in everyday life and the capacity of the human species. The Soviet Union had launched the first artificial satellite, a new moon, on Oct. 4, 1957. Climbing out of the terrestrial gravity well, rising above the atmosphere and into orbit, Sputnik crossed the threshold into a new dimension of human experience. People could now see their kind as spacefarers. Their enhanced mobility might someday prove as liberating as the first upright steps of hominid ancestors long ago.

results.abstract: Homer H Hickam, Ernst Stuhlinger, Walter Cronkite, Esther Dyson, Sir Martin Rees, Neil deGrasse Tyson, Ursula K Le Guin, Margaret J Geller, Tom Lehrer, Edward T Lu and Jose Vazquez describe what they experienced when Russia launched Sputnik in 1957; photos (L)
results.snippet: The New York Times asked scientists and others who lived through it (and a few who were yet to be born) to reflect on what Sputnik meant to them.
results.lead_paragraph: The launching of Sputnik on Oct. 4, 1957, was a life-changing event -- one that ignited imaginations, dictated the course of careers, and changed the way people thought about science, education and global politics. The New York Times asked scientists and others who lived through it (and a few who were yet to be born) to reflect on what Sputnik meant to them. Homer H. Hickam, 64, author of ''Rocket Boys,'' a memoir adapted for the movie ''October Sky.''

results.abstract: Michael D Griffin, NASA Administrator, reports in journal Aviation Week and Space Technology that there is no certain path for future research; holds that predicting future of space exploration over next fifty years is impossible task; experts in industry say that NASA will likely return to Moon by 2020 and establish research outpost there; hold that private enterprise will likely move ahead of many government-sponsored space programs; drawing (M)

headline.main: New Horizons Beckon, Inspiring Vision if Not Certainty

results.snippet: Moon or Mars, or both? Economic incentives or political? And who will lead the way?
results.lead_paragraph: Fifty years of spaceflight have taken people to the Moon and have sent unmanned vehicles zipping to the fringes of the solar system. What could the next 50 years bring? Much more, or potentially not much more. Government-financed space travel could stall in the face of America's growing aversion to risk and a kind of orbital ennui. NASA has, after all, already tried for more than a decade to develop follow-on vehicles to the flawed space shuttle and is in the process of trying again.
